Topic.Title: Pumping stox like this pig with markets at theze levelz iz

Message.Msg: "Breakout coming." You don't want to be left out when that happens. $320 within a month.

Message.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?
Message.Msg: I know I'm taking a big risk here in asking a serious question . . ., but does anyone know of a stock that had Amazon's Market Cap and Amazon's 300 P/E ratio that ever had a gentle glide back into "normal" ranges. Has a company that has already gotten this big ever grown it's earnings in a way as to reduce it's P/E gradually? I'm not saying Amazon's not a great company. As a company it has nearly everything going for it. I'm not bashing here, but as a STOCK, is it that great? Is it not extremely more likely that a significant correction back down to market-average Price-to-Earnings and Price-to-Book ratios is in store? Any market historians out there care to weight in? If it's ever been done before, maybe I'll change my outlook.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: ". . . but does anyone know of a stock that had Amazon's Market Cap and Amazon's 300 P/E ratio that ever had a gentle glide back into "normal" ranges." No, AMZN will not have "a gentle glide back into "normal" ranges." She will suddenly doubling, tripling, and quadrupling violently to reduce her P/E to more "reasonable" level. Don't you see $320 is coming within a month? She's not a stock to short for people like shorts here who just like to kill time getting engaged leisurely armchair discussions forever.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: Thanks for the comment, but I was hoping for an actual historically documented case of when a company this mature ever quadrupled it's earnings in order to bring down it's P/E. If $320 a share is coming in a month, that would make the P/E ratio grow to 400 and seemingly make the P/E imbalance that much greater. Wouldn't investing in a much smaller company make more sense?

Message.Title: AMZN vs. AAPL - AMZN grossly undervalued.
Message.Msg: If you think AAPL is undervalued or fairly valued, then AMZN is grossly undervalued. Revenues per share and today's closing price: AAPL: 159.61 and 675.68 AMZN: 119.93 and 243.92 See, if you believe AAPL is undervalued or fairly valued as you've been claiming for years, AMZN should be at least $507.70. $507.70! Bwahahahaha . . . Bwahahahaha . . . Bwahahahaha . . .

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: AAPL's earnings/share: June 30, 2012 9.32 March 31, 2012 12.30 Dec. 31, 2011 13.87 Sept. 30, 2011 7.06 June 30, 2011 7.79 March 31, 2011 6.40 Dec. 31, 2010 6.43 Sept. 30, 2010 4.64 June 30, 2010 3.51 March 31, 2010 3.33 Dec. 31, 2009 3.67 Sept. 30, 2009 2.78 June 30, 2009 2.01 March 31, 2009 1.79 Dec. 31, 2008 2.50 Sept. 30, 2008 2.67 AAPL's price on September 30, 2008: $113.17 Assuming the number of outstanding shares of AAPL hasn't changed much, we can estimate the market cap of Apple on September 30, 2008 to be about $106 billion. AAPL's closing price and Apple's market cap today: $675.68 a share and $633.39 billion. So it is definitely possible for a $100 billion company to quadruple its earnings.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: Forgot to give credit to the source of earnings per share data: ycharts.com

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: Apple Inc.'s earnings per share: June 30, 2012 9.32 March 31, 2012 12.30 Dec. 31, 2011 13.87 Sept. 30, 2011 7.06 June 30, 2011 7.79 March 31, 2011 6.40 Dec. 31, 2010 6.43 Sept. 30, 2010 4.64 June 30, 2010 3.51 March 31, 2010 3.33 Dec. 31, 2009 3.67 Sept. 30, 2009 2.78 June 30, 2009 2.01 March 31, 2009 1.79 Dec. 31, 2008 2.50 Sept. 30, 2008 2.67 Four quarters total (Sept. 30, 2008 - June 30, 2009): 8.97 Four quarters total (Sept. 30, 2011 - June 30, 2012): 42.56 Apple Inc.'s earnings growth over the last four years: 474.36%. So, their earnings have more than quadrupled in four (4) years. AAPL's closing price on Sept 30, 2008: $113.17 per share Assuming the number of AAPL's outstanding shares hasn't change much in four (4) years (about 937 million shares), the market capitalization of Apple Inc. should have been about $106 billion. So, it is definitely possible for a $100 billion company to quadruple its earnings in four years. Incidentally, AAPL's closing price today (August 27, 2012) is $675.68 per share. The stock price has increased by more than sixfold.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: Bart: this is probably not a good example, but in the early days of INTC, when INTC would go on a capital expansion program, it always marked the beginning of a new bull market. Needless to say, the PE would be high or non-existent, scaring value players out of the stock. At the end of the bull market, INTC would stop all building due to overcapacity, And the PE would plummet, causing bulls to hold onto their shares at precisely the wrong time.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: AAPL and INTC or most other companies have a product to sell with a profit margin. AMZN has limited products that are break even or losing money. Their prime program is about to implode. Prime shipping is causing losses. Bezos will have to increase the price just like Hastings tried at NetFlix. Same result will take place. Eventually making money will matter over revenue expansion. The only thing holding AMZN up is the high institutional ownership. If even one institution decides to get out, look out. I have not read any post on this board ever from someone pumping AMZN that explains how they will ever increase margins. All pumpers are just high on Bezos and revenue growth. All it will take is one institution to care about making money over revenue expansion and AMZN will come back to its PE. Who knows when that will take place.

Topic.Title: Any Market Historians Out There . . . ?

Message.Msg: Take a look at the airline stocks. For years they did not care about profit and kept flying unprofitable routes to not let their their competitors have certain markets alone. All they cared about was revenue growth. They were loved by institutional owners. Look at them now. All the major airlines have gone through chapter 11 reorganization and stock holders lost all their investment. AMZN continues to go backwards on profitability. The products they release are breakeven or losing money. Prime membership is a time bomb. I would love to read an answer from some of the pumpers on this board on how they will begin increasing margins. All you will get is Bezos is the man or look at the expansion and revenue growth.

Topic.Title: AMZN vs. AAPL - AMZN grossly undervalued.

Message.Msg: Wow - that sounds like the logic used right before the dot.com bust. Do earnings come into play? What about growth of revenue and earnings. Lets just take earnings. The PE is the most respected valuation measure around. If AAPL had a PE similiar to AMZN, then AAPL would be trading at $12,679.90. If AMZN had a PE similiar to AAPLE then AMZN would be trading at $12.97 If both had a PE of 30 the price would be" AAPL - $1,276.50 AMZN - $24.60 AMZN is a freek under any comparisons and something that will have to correct itself.

Message.Title: MM's Ran AMZN up for Insiders (and lower level employees) to Sell - Stock will Now Fall
Message.Msg: The Nasdaq Specialist always run a stock up when options are exercised so that insiders can sell. Many people don't realize that employees below corporate officers and directors don't have to file SEC forms. There were hundreds of thousands shares issued to lower level employees. The Specialist then pushes the price up to let them sell. Momentum buyers and short covering also come in to take price to unsustainable levels. The same thing happened at SBUX a few months back and then price fell 25%. All stock has now been sold by employees and insiders AMZN is now ready to fall.

Topic.Title: AMZN vs. AAPL - AMZN grossly undervalued.

Message.Msg: I couldn't agree with you more sammmy. You hit the nail on the head. Geegenjar must be smoking whatever it is that the funds buying this dog are smoking.. I presume the logic is that at some point AMZN will be able to somehow magically increase margins, but I thought the AMZN business model was built around low margins to generate revenues in the first place. AMZN earned $0.81/share in the past year, and is expected to LOSE money the current quarter. There's a very good reason that PE is a highly respected valuation measure, based on common sense... Who in their right mind would pay out $250 to get back $0.81/year, other than in an FDIC insured bank savings account? AMZN earnings estimate for next year is $2.38... At that rate it would still take over 100 years to get your money back based on earnings and current share price. AAPL is expected to earn $44/share this year and $52/share next year. This means only 15 years to get your money back based on earnings, plus you get back over 1% CASH in the form of a dividend... There is just no comparison between the two companies. I think this is bandwagon thinking and tacit agreement among fund managers to hold onto this dog and let it run, lest their returns get decimated and they lose their jobs... Why should this company be awarded with a 300 times earnings valuation? It makes just no sense, and is exactly like the dot com era when people bid up companies until they woke up and realized that a company needs to make money in order to be really worth something.. Everybody got sold on the story that we need to come up with new valuation metrics for these companies, which is pure #$%$.. If there were prospects in place for big margin growth, then ok, I can understand, but as it is, I just don't see it.

Topic.Title: 1987 crash -25 year ago in October....

Message.Msg: i sold a 33 Buick 3-window coupe that day. i bought it for 900 bucks. Replaced all the wood in the floor with 1" sq. tubing and 16 guage steel. Chopped the top, suicided the doors, put a 401 Nailhead engine in it with a turbo 400 trans and sold the car for 3500 bucks on that memorable day. i might have made 5 bucks an hour for my labor. The buyer later took the 401 out and put in a big block chevy...What was the name of that Dire Straits song?? Working for nothing....

Topic.Title: AMZN vs. AAPL - AMZN grossly undervalued.

Message.Msg: Some idiots only look at gross revenues and forget to take into account net income after taxes. You've got a Goliath here that's creating enormous overhead in warehousing and yet working dangerously low margins and now with a sales tax load that will make prices less attractive .

Topic.Title: AMZN in Texas SALES TAX Starts - 7 States to follow!

Message.Msg: In most companies with high PE you expect the "E" to grow. In Amazon's case the earnings will be shrinking due to: 1)ban by groups against AMZN support of gay marriage 2)Increase in shipping costs caused by high gasoline 3)Sales tax collection makes products no longer competitive 4)Increased competition by Apple. Some honest analyst will pick up on this and you'll wake up to a sell rating and the stock down at least 10 bucks.

Fidelity Names Abigail Johnson President Aug. 28 (Bloomberg) -- Fidelity Investments, the second- biggest U.S. mutual-fund company, named Abigail P. Johnson president after consolidating all of the firm’s key units under her leadership, making her the industry’s highest-ranking woman. Johnson, 50, will oversee asset management, retail and institutional brokerage, retirement and benefits services, the Boston-based firm said today in a statement. She will report to Edward C. “Ned” Johnson III, her father, who remains the company’s chairman and chief executive officer.
